channel.title: Wavefront OBJ Viewer
channel.description:
This is my very third program ever in C#. Actually, I've lost count. It parses a wavefront obj file, gets the vertex data, then displays it with OpenGL. It doesn't support textures or anything, basically only vertex groups.
[img]http://jwarez.net/pics/3de7c2a2219f20fac90035469faef235.PNG[/img] (Notice the Gouraud shading is is fucked up, I don't think I'm doing it right)
Loaded from http://pastebin.ca/1175295
Hacked up src is in svn at https://spark3d.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/spark3d/OBJ/ It's only a proof of concept, and will be rewritten properly as a base for my 3D engine.
I used the Tao.OpenGL bindings, and because it's OpenGL, the drawing is fast as fuck. I know nobody here gives a shit, but I just like posting crap that I make :)

item.title: Wavefront OBJ Viewer
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

I tried… 

        public Vector3D Normal
        {
            get
            {
                System.Diagnostics.Debug.Assert(this.Vertices.Count > 2);
                Vector3D v = this.Vertices[0].Location - this.Vertices[2].Location;
                Vector3D u = this.Vertices[1].Location - this.Vertices[2].Location;
                Vector3D n = new Vector3D(v.Y * u.Z - v.Z * u.Y, v.Z * u.X - v.X * u.Z, v.X * u.Y - v.Y * u.X);
                //Console.WriteLine(v.ToString() + " :: " + u.ToString() + " :: " + n.ToString());
                return n;
            }
        }

Will fix it soon.

Fix’d, had to normalize the normals, and delimit the polygons.
Still have no idea why the light removes all my colors ;\

Read full topic

item.title: Wavefront OBJ Viewer
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

ah, ok. If you take a look a bentski’s source you’ll find some normal calculation routines in the FileRSM unit, easily ported. You might look at the drawing routine, in main, as well to see how they are used.
Gouraud shading relies on vertex normals to calculate the shading gradient you should be seeing.

Sounds like your loading properly.

As for your vertex order, don’t worry about it, opengl’s backface culling will show you if your doing it wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: Wavefront OBJ Viewer
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“MrPotatoHead, post:7, topic:226725”]Very nice.
It’s your vertex normals, you shouldn’t be seeing the face edges in the middle.
But this could also be because the model faces all have seperate vertices, or your loading the model into memory wrong. Check make sure your reusing vertices and haven’t copied them for each face. If that makes any sense.[/quote]
I’m not even specifying any normals…probably my first mistake. Also, I’m not even checking to see if a vertex already exists, I’m just calling glVertex3f for every single “v” in the obj file, no sorting or anything. The polygons are probably not being drawn in counterclockwise order either, so OpenGL thinks that we are looking at the back of the face for some, and the front for others.

Read full topic

item.title: Wavefront OBJ Viewer
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Very nice.
It’s your vertex normals, you shouldn’t be seeing the face edges in the middle.
But this could also be because the model faces all have seperate vertices, or your loading the model into memory wrong. Check make sure your reusing vertices and haven’t copied them for each face. If that makes any sense.

Read full topic

Only other one I’ve tried is NetBeans for java, and that was the most fucking fail Ive ever felt in my life.

item.title: Wavefront OBJ Viewer
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:4, topic:226725”][quote author=the bank link=topic=297963.msg2394020#msg2394020 date=1219084053]

In C#, do you have to write the GUI as in Java or can you just drag and drop like in Delphi? It’s a .net language so my guess is drag and drop, but you never know.
[/quote]There are many, many, many drag & drop editors for java applications.

Just expanding on this, they’re called WYSIWYG editors(Delphi/VB6 can be described as a RAD Tool, Rapid Application Development Tool), generally it’s almost always better to do to do it by hand when you can/[/quote]
Visual Studio allows you to drag and drop the .NET controls, as well as custom controls you create.

The Visual Studio designer is incredibly advanced (compared to any Java ones I’ve tried) so there is absolutely no benefit to writing it by hand as far as I can see.

Read full topic

This is my very third program ever in C#.
Actually, I’ve lost count.
It parses a wavefront obj file, gets the vertex data, then displays it with OpenGL. It doesn’t support textures or anything, basically only vertex groups.


(Notice the Gouraud shading is is fucked up, I don’t think I’m doing it right)

Hacked up src is in svn at
